What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about what it takes to write a body of ethnographic work, from interviewing to creating fieldnotes to actually producing a mini-ethnography for the final.
How to write field notes and ethnographic texts.
I gained a greater understanding of performing ethnographic fieldwork and writing ethnographies through hands-on experience doing both, through a guided ethnographic project.
I learned that anthropology is a way to see what might have become "invisible," and how to share that through ethnographic writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: Yukiko is an incredible instructor that will push you to produce an amazing product. She is approachable and so eager to help her students. I also appreciate that the syllabus is light on the reading and really gives you the space to dive 100% into your ethnographic writing. Weakness: Yukiko's grading may seem harsh at the beginning and discouraging, but at least in my experience, the final grade she give me was extremely fair, and dare I say generous. So don't worry about your grade when taking this course; as Yukiko says, grades are a great heuristic to help you understand how far you need to go to produce a top-tier product.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to another student if they are interested in producing ethnographic work in the future or if they are interested in socio-cultural anthropology. I have always enjoyed reading ethnographies, but writing one was certainly not for me.
Good class for workshoping an ethnography. You will get great feedback and get to develop your ideas over a long period of time.
Yes, I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. It is engaging, interesting, and overall a great learning experience.

Yes. If you are serious about anthropology, this class will help you understand what anthropology truly is. I've taken 4 or 5 anthropology courses before this, but now I realize I did not grasp the power of anthropology and what a special discipline it is until taking this class. Anthropology is not just interviewing people and writing down what they say; it is a way to help your reader see the world through both your interlocutors' and your eyes. It is not an easy class; not because of the workload, but because of the intense thinking required to create truly meaningful and impactful ethnographic writing. But this class has taught me more than any other anthropology class I've ever taken. It's made me a much better listener and writer, and I appreciate ethnographies much more now that I've had a taste of writing one myself.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
